title: A Red Carpet Honor: THCF Recognized at Hooray for Englewood
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
We were deeply humbled and honored to be named the Honorary Chair at the inaugural Hooray for Englewood Gala, held on May 31 at the Englewood Arts Center.

This red-carpet affair was a dazzling celebration of community, creativity, and revitalization ‚Äî and we were truly moved to be recognized among so many passionate champions of the arts.

The Hooray for Englewood event brought the glamour of classic Hollywood to the heart of Independence, all in support of the inspiring mission of Englewood Arts. The beautiful evening featured community spirit, vintage attire, and a shared vision for a thriving creative district ‚Äî and it was all set beneath the stars, in the buzzing outdoor space of the newly renovated arts center.

During the program, our Foundation was recognized for our longstanding support of Englewood Arts, and CEO Phil Hanson accepted the honor on behalf of our Board, staff, and donors. 

In a heartfelt moment, Englewood Arts Director, Teresa Dorsch, shared these powerful words:

‚ÄúThere is so much I can share. From the very beginning, you believed in the vision of Englewood Arts. When we were just a small, scrappy group of go-getters, your early and generous support tremendously helped us ‚Äî by giving others the confidence to support our mission, encouraging us to move forward with our housing initiatives, and helping us transform a dilapidated building into what it is today: a welcoming community arts center here in Independence.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour ongoing support of Englewood Arts has been truly instrumental in our journey, laying the groundwork for the programs we‚Äôre celebrating tonight.‚Äù

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we are proud to invest in local leaders and organizations that build stronger communities ‚Äî and Englewood Arts is a shining example. Since acquiring their building in 2019, they have transformed it into a vibrant hub for visual arts, performing arts, and culinary arts ‚Äî offering everything from glassblowing workshops and kids‚Äô camps to live performances and creative learning opportunities for all ages.

Proceeds from the Gala will support their continued growth, including expanded programming, additional classes and workshops, and upgrades to make the facility more accessible to all.

We extend our heartfelt congratulations to the Englewood Arts team for an unforgettable evening and a remarkable journey ‚Äî one that we are proud to walk alongside. It was an evening filled with gratitude, celebration, and community ‚Äî and one we won‚Äôt soon forget.

To learn more about Englewood Arts and how to get involved, visit www.englewoodarts.art

title: Youth Who Give Back: A Community Celebration of Service
author: Phil Hanson MPA CAP¬Æ
body:
This year, we had 70 high school students from 10 high schools who were actively engaged in our school of philanthropy. Of the active students, 28 are graduating seniors, and we had the opportunity to hear from 9 of them who were able to attend the picnic and share their thoughts on the program.

Like for many of you, it‚Äôs graduation season at the Truman Heartland Community Foundation. On May 15th we had our annual graduation picnic for our Youth Advisory Council (YAC). 

It‚Äôs always heartwarming to listen to them share their experiences and hear about their heart for service and joy in giving back to the community. The seniors shared their words of advice to those continuing in the program. We also heard from several continuing students who expressed their appreciation to the seniors for their support, friendship, and leadership. 

The slogan for our YAC program, emblazoned on their official t-shirt, is ‚ÄúEmpowering students to change their community through philanthropy.‚Äù It‚Äôs wonderful to see students from 10 high schools in our region coming together to serve the community. Typically, when students from various schools come together, the focus is on competition rather than community building. 

As I shared with the students in my brief welcoming remarks, they truly enable our Community Foundation to do our work better and have a greater impact on the community. One service they provide is reviewing grant applications from our competitive grants process and doing site visits. 

Last summer, they reviewed 16 applications and made site visits and then shared their analysis with our grants committee. The adults on our grants committee consistently provide positive feedback about the students and the information they bring to the discussions. Our YAC students will be busy again this summer reviewing grants and making site visits. So, there is no summer break for our school of philanthropy.

The students also have the opportunity to make grants from their endowment fund, which they have built up over the years. Their endowment fund now has more than $117,000, including the $4,300 they added to it this year as the result of their Strike in the Night fundraiser held at Lunar Bowl. 

Last year, they made grants of $1,363 each to Lee‚Äôs Summit Meals on Wheels, Marian Hope, and Sleep in Heavenly Peace, totaling $4,089. 

In April, 40 students participated in their annual Fill Those Trucks food drive to support the Community Services League, Raytown Emergency Assistance Program, and Lee‚Äôs Summit Social Services. We appreciate the support of Hy-Vee in allowing our students to be at 4 area locations to help these 3 organizations stock their shelves for the summer season, which traditionally has a higher need for food assistance since school is not in session.

We are very proud of our YAC graduates and know that the lessons they learned about philanthropy and service will go with them as they find their place and make their mark on the world. 

 

 

 

Truman Heartland Community Foundation is a public charity committed to improving area communities by promoting and serving private giving for the public good. Founded in 1982, THCF serves individuals who, through their private giving, wish to support the public good in the most tax-wise and effective manner. Through THCF, donors can set up their own family foundations, scholarship funds, field of interest funds, endowment funds, charitable gift annuities, and many other charitable vehicles that utilize the foundation‚Äôs shared resources to maximize the impact of their philanthropic dollars. In addition to donor services, THCF provides asset development for nonprofit organizations, offers competitive grant opportunities to nonprofits, assists organizations in planned giving, and serves as a change leader in addressing community issues. For more information, visit www.thcf.org or call 816-836-8189.

title: Behind the Scenes: Transforming Lives at CSL‚Äôs Eastern Jackson County Drop-In Center
author: Melanie Adkins
body:
Strategically located at the crossroads of Kansas City, Independence, and Raytown, the Drop-In Center is the only facility of its kind east of 435 Highway, making it a critical resource for Eastern Jackson County.

This week, Truman Heartland Community Foundation (THCF) hosted a special Behind-the-Scenes tour of the Community Services League‚Äôs (CSL) Eastern Jackson County Drop-In Center ‚Äî a vital refuge providing life-changing support for unsheltered individuals in our region. 

The City of Independence has been a strong supporter of this initiative, working alongside CSL to ensure the center meets the pressing needs of the community.

A Community Collaboration for Compassion and Change

During the tour, our fundholders heard from THCF President and CEO Phil Hanson, who highlighted the importance of supporting initiatives like the Drop-In Center. CEO Doug Cowan of Community Services League shared the impact of the center, which opened in February 2025 and has already served over 350 visitors. The Drop-In Center offers a range of critical services ‚Äî from providing meals and hygiene items to assisting with essential documents like IDs and birth certificates, which are often barriers to securing employment and housing.

Pastor Andreas Stavno, the leader of Good Shepherd Community of Christ, spoke about how hosting the Drop-In Center is a natural extension of the church‚Äôs mission of loving your neighbor. His message of compassion and community responsibility resonated deeply with those in attendance.

Expanding to Meet Critical Needs

While the Drop-In Center has already made a tremendous impact, there is much more to be done. CEO Doug Cowan announced that CSL is launching a $750,000 capital campaign to enhance the facility, adding private bathrooms, showers, and laundry facilities for guests. Plans also include creating private office spaces for case management, ensuring that guests receive personalized support in a secure and respectful environment.

In a show of support, THCF President and CEO Phil Hanson announced a $10,000 gift from the Truman Heartland Community Foundation to CSL, encouraging THCF fundholders to consider joining the effort. ‚ÄúThis is a crucial resource for our community,‚Äù Phil shared, ‚Äúand we have an opportunity to support its growth and ensure its success.‚Äù

How You Can Help

As we left the Drop-In Center, our group was inspired by the dedication of CSL‚Äôs team, the compassion of Good Shepherd Community of Christ, and the resilience of the guests who are finding hope and stability within its walls. But there is more to be done.

If you would like to support CSL‚Äôs Eastern Jackson County Drop-In Center and its $750,000 fundraising goal, you can make a direct contribution or recommend a grant from your Donor-Advised Fund with THCF. Together, we can ensure that this life-changing resource continues to serve those in need.

To learn more or to make a gift through your fund, please contact Diana Castillo us at Truman Heartland Community Foundation.

title: Announcing our 2025 Toast to Our Towns Honorees for Exceptional Philanthropy
author: Phil Hanson MPA CAP¬Æ
body:
Each year, the Foundation recognizes outstanding individuals, businesses, and organizations whose generosity, leadership, and commitment have made a significant difference across Eastern Jackson County and the surrounding region.

This is always a fun time of year when we have the privilege of announcing our honorees for the Truman Heartland Community Foundation (THCF Toast to Our Towns Gala. This year, our 30th Annual Gala will be held Saturday, September 20, 2025, at the Westin Kansas City at Crown Center. 

Our 2025 honorees embody the spirit of philanthropy, service, and resilience that strengthens our communities.  We are proud to celebrate their remarkable contributions and the positive impact they continue to make in our region.

 

The 2025 Toast to Our Towns Gala Honorees are:

Humanitarian of the Year ‚Äì Michele Shanahan DeMoss

After the tragic loss of her 11-year-old daughter, Blair, who was killed by a stray bullet from celebratory gunfire on the Fourth of July, Michele became a tireless advocate for public safety. She successfully championed "Blair‚Äôs Law," which criminalizes reckless celebratory gunfire in Missouri. Michele is also the founder of Blair‚Äôs Foster Socks, a nonprofit supporting children in foster care, and operates a small business in Independence. Her work is a powerful example of transforming personal loss into lasting impact for others.

Corporate Citizen of the Year ‚Äì Cornell Roofing & Sheet Metal

With nearly a century of service in the Kansas City area, Cornell Roofing exemplifies community leadership through its support of local nonprofits, educational scholarships, and initiatives like Englewood Arts and Habitat for Humanity. Under the leadership of Mary McNamara, an industry trailblazer, Cornell continues to make a lasting difference.

Heartland Service Award ‚Äì Metropolitan Community College (MCC)

For over 100 years, MCC has provided accessible education while leading workforce development and civic engagement efforts throughout the region. The college has empowered tens of thousands of students‚Äîmany of them first-generation college attendees‚Äîto achieve academic success and secure meaningful employment. Through initiatives like the Job Skills Initiative, the Path Forward Capital Campaign, and the Civic Action Plan, MCC‚Äôs commitment to students, community growth, and regional leadership has left a transformative legacy.

In addition to celebrating these exceptional honorees, the Gala will also recognize Citizens of the Year selected by the mayors of Eastern Jackson County municipalities‚Äîhighlighting individuals who have demonstrated extraordinary service and leadership at the local level. Stay tuned this summer for more information about the Citizen‚Äôs honored by our Mayors. 

With the Presenting Sponsor of Blue Ridge Bank and Trust, proceeds from the Toast to Our Towns Gala support Truman Heartland Community Foundation‚Äôs work in promoting private giving for the public good, including initiatives in education, workforce development, and community betterment. 

Sponsorships, tables, and individual tickets are available now. For more information about the Gala or to make reservations, please visit www.thcf.org/gala.

title: Building a Legacy: How Scholarship Funds Create Opportunities for Students
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
Education is a powerful tool that transforms lives, and at Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we believe in the profound impact of providing educational opportunities to local students.

Since 1982, our fundholders have awarded over $7.5 million in scholarships, empowering students to pursue higher education and achieve their dreams. In 2024 alone, our scholarship program awarded $828,181 in scholarships to 334 students through 461 individual awards, thanks to the generosity of our fundholders who established and maintained 173 scholarship funds.

These scholarships represent more than just financial support. They are a testament to the belief in the potential of each student, a way to honor loved ones, and a means to invest in the future of our community. Whether you are passionate about a particular field of study, want to support students from a specific school, or honor the memory of a loved one, establishing a scholarship fund at Truman Heartland Community Foundation is a meaningful way to make a lasting difference.

How You Can Make a Difference

Creating a scholarship fund is a simple and impactful way to leave a legacy. Here‚Äôs how you can get started:

  1. Choose Your Fund Type: Start with a gift of $25,000 or more, which can be made using cash, appreciated securities, real estate, or other assets.
  2. Define Your Scholarship Criteria: Work with our experienced team to design eligibility criteria that reflect your values, such as field of study, academic achievements, extracurricular activities, or financial need.
  3. Personalize Your Fund: Your scholarship fund can bear your name, the name of a loved one, or any name you choose.
  4. Select the Award Process: You can choose to be directly involved in the selection process through an advisory committee, or you can leave the selection to our dedicated Scholarship Committee.
  5. Trust Our Expertise: We handle the administrative details, including application management, fund administration, and award distribution.
  6. See the Impact: Each year, your scholarship fund will help deserving students reach their educational goals, creating a lasting impact in our community.

A Legacy of Generosity

The stories behind our scholarship recipients are a source of inspiration. Students who may have never considered higher education are given a chance to pursue their dreams because of the generosity of donors like you. Our scholarship fundholders come from all walks of life, but they share a common commitment to education and a desire to make a difference.  

One of our more recent Scholarship Success stories includes Katie Ameku, who has become a 2025 Rhodes Scholar, and she attributes much of her success to the scholarships received through THCF donors. 

If you are passionate about education and want to create a lasting legacy, we invite you to explore the possibilities of establishing a scholarship fund at Truman Heartland Community Foundation. Join us in empowering the next generation and making a positive impact on our community.

Ready to learn more? Review some of the FAQs about Scholarship Funds here, or contact us to start building your legacy today.

title: Understanding Community Foundations: How We Connect Generosity with Impact
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
For many people, the idea of giving back to their community is a deeply held value. But figuring out how to make a meaningful impact can sometimes feel overwhelming. That‚Äôs where Truman Heartland Community Foundation (THCF) comes in ‚Äî a trusted partner for individuals, families, and businesses who want to create positive change.

What Is a Community Foundation?

A community foundation is a nonprofit organization created to connect people who care with causes that matter. It‚Äôs like a charitable hub ‚Äî a place where generosity can be transformed into real impact, providing donors with a range of options for giving back.

At THCF, we make giving easy and effective. Whether you want to support education, health and human services, the arts, environmental causes, or another passion, we help you create a fund that aligns with your charitable goals. Our professional team manages all administrative details, so you can focus on the joy of giving.

How Does THCF Help Donors?

We offer a variety of fund types to meet the needs and interests of our donors:

  • Donor-Advised Funds: A flexible, tax-advantaged way for individuals, families, or businesses to support the causes they care about. You recommend grants to nonprofits of your choice, while we handle the paperwork. In 2024, THCF managed 320 Donor Advised Funds, processed 1,803 grant requests, facilitating more than $4.5 million in grants to local nonprofits. This reflects our donors' commitment to making a tangible impact in Eastern Jackson County and the surrounding communities.
  • Scholarship Funds: Create a lasting legacy by supporting students pursuing higher education. In 2024 alone, THCF awarded $828,181 in scholarships to 334 students through 461 individual awards, thanks to the generosity of fundholders who established and maintained 173 scholarship funds.
  • Field of Interest Funds: Support a specific cause, such as arts, education, or health, while we ensure your gift is directed to the most impactful programs.
  • Designated Funds: Provide ongoing support to specific organizations that you care about, such as a local museum, food pantry, or educational program.
  • Agency Funds: Local nonprofits can establish funds to ensure their financial sustainability and long-term success.
  • Unrestricted Funds: Give our Foundation the flexibility to address the greatest needs in the community as they arise.

Why Choose a Community Foundation?

Unlike a private foundation, which requires significant resources and administrative responsibilities, a community foundation like THCF provides an efficient and cost-effective way to achieve your charitable goals. Our donors receive:

‚úÖ Expertise: Our experienced team provides personalized service, ensuring that your charitable giving is effective and tax-efficient.


‚úÖ Flexibility: We offer a wide range of fund types, so you can give in the way that makes the most sense for you.


‚úÖ Community Impact: Most grants stay local, supporting the causes and organizations that make Eastern Jackson County a better place to live.

A Legacy of Generosity

Since our founding, THCF has connected generous individuals, families, and businesses with opportunities to make a difference. Our impact is seen in the students who receive scholarships, the nonprofits that receive vital support, and the countless lives touched by the kindness of our donors.

Would you like to learn more about how you can create a fund and make a difference? Visit our DAF FAQ's page or contact Cole Eason to get started.

title: Celebrating 20 Years of Advisor Education: Join Us for Our Spring 2025 Professional Advisor Seminar
author: Cole Eason JD
body:
For two decades, Truman Heartland Community Foundation has proudly supported the professional advisor community with meaningful, high-quality educational opportunities. As we celebrate 20 years of hosting our Professional Advisor Seminars, we invite you to join us this spring for a timely and informative session focused on the evolving challenges of estate planning.

Our Spring 2025 Professional Advisor Seminar will be held on Thursday, May 15, 2025, from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. at Midwest Public Risk in Independence, Missouri. This event is free to attend and open to attorneys, accountants, financial planners, and other professionals interested in deepening their expertise in estate and charitable planning.

This year‚Äôs session is titled:

title: Federal Funding and Local Nonprofits
author: Phil Hanson MPA CAP¬Æ
body:
There is a great deal of stress amongst the leaders of the local nonprofit sector due to the uncertainty with federal government funding. Let‚Äôs take a moment to explore the reasons for that stress and the complex relationship between nonprofits and federal funding.

The White House Office of Management and Budget issued a memo on January 27, instructing all federal agencies to pause all open grants and loans. This action would have a devastating impact on nonprofits serving our Eastern Jackson County communities. 

 

Local Impact of the White House January Memo

The memo prompted the staff and board leadership of many local nonprofits to hold emergency meetings and assess the potential crisis for their organizations. Fortunately, after lawsuits were filed in opposition, the memo was rescinded. 

While the level of stress has decreased somewhat, there is still a significant amount of uncertainty for many nonprofits due to the complex relationships between nonprofits and federal funding. Let's explore a few aspects of that relationship. 

First, in my opinion, one of the few things that everyone can agree on is that we are against waste, fraud, and abuse in government spending. It is also my opinion that the federal grants that support local nonprofits in providing services to some of the most vulnerable individuals in our communities are one of the most effective tools for combating waste, fraud, and abuse. 

These organizations are led by individuals from our communities who understand best how to meet the needs within our communities. This is a much better system than someone in Washington, DC, designing these programs. These nonprofits can also generate other charitable local resources to address these needs. 

 

Examining the Third Sector

The Nonprofit Sector is sometimes referred to as the ‚ÄúThird Sector,‚Äù with Private enterprise as the ‚ÄúFirst Sector‚Äù and Government as the ‚ÄúSecond Sector.‚Äù Let us explore the complex relationship between the Second and Third Sectors.

"...charitable giving in 2023 was $557 billion, with 75% coming from individuals or their estates. In 2023 it increased by 1.9%. To replace the $303 billion in federal funding that is being eliminated now, charitable giving would need to increase by a whopping 54%."

A study was done by Candid, a nonprofit that provides data and insights on the social sector, of the 990 tax returns filed by nonprofits for 2023 (the most current data available). This study shows that 30% of the nonprofits filing 990s received government grants, and the total amount of these grants that year was $303 Billion.

Let‚Äôs put this $303 billion in perspective. In fiscal year 2024, Total Federal Government Spending is projected to be $6.8 trillion. Of that total, $303 billion awarded in government grants to nonprofits is just 4.5%.

 

Can Charitable Giving Make Up for the Loss in Federal Funding?

Some might suggest that these services are best funded through charitable giving. According to Giving USA, total charitable giving in 2023 was $557 billion, with 75% coming from individuals or their estates. In 2023 it increased by 1.9%. To replace the $303 billion in federal funding that is being eliminated now, charitable giving would need to increase by a whopping 54%. 

Therefore, the anxiety among nonprofits about federal funding is to be expected. Charitable giving simply cannot make up for government grants to nonprofits, even though our country leads the world in charitable giving. 

As I mentioned earlier, in my opinion, grants to nonprofit organizations are one of the most effective tools for combating waste, fraud, and abuse. This is because they are managed and implemented at the local level. I hope we can all maintain this perspective as the changes in federal spending continue to evolve. Let‚Äôs not throw the proverbial ‚Äúbaby out with the bathwater.‚Äù 

 

Truman Heartland Community Foundation is a public charity committed to improving area communities by promoting and serving private giving for the public good. Founded in 1982, THCF serves individuals who, through their private giving, wish to support the public good in the most tax-wise and effective manner. Through THCF, donors can set up their own family foundations, scholarship funds, field of interest funds, endowment funds, charitable gift annuities, and many other charitable vehicles that utilize the foundation‚Äôs shared resources to maximize the impact of their philanthropic dollars. In addition to donor services, THCF provides asset development for nonprofit organizations, offers competitive grant opportunities to nonprofits, assists organizations in planned giving, and serves as a change leader in addressing community issues. For more information, visit www.thcf.org or call 816-836-8189.

title: Future-Proof Your Mission: A Nonprofit‚Äôs Guide to Launching (or Leveling Up) Planned Giving
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
In today‚Äôs uncertain climate, future-proofing your mission isn‚Äôt just smart‚Äîit‚Äôs essential. With potential shifts in federal funding on the horizon, many nonprofits are facing new questions about long-term sustainability.

While no one can predict exactly how policies or priorities may change, what‚Äôs clear is that relying solely on traditional funding streams is becoming increasingly risky. That‚Äôs where planned giving comes in. These legacy gifts create a more stable, resilient financial foundation that helps your organization stay focused on impact, no matter what tomorrow brings.

 

What is Planned Giving, Really?

Planned giving‚Äîalso called legacy giving‚Äîis when donors commit future gifts through their estate plans. These are often made via a will, trust, beneficiary designation, or even more sophisticated vehicles like charitable gift annuities or charitable remainder trusts. While these gifts may not arrive right away, they offer long-term financial security that allows your organization to dream bigger, plan farther, and weather the unexpected.

 

Why Nonprofits of All Sizes Should Care

Whether your nonprofit is large or small, now is the time to start thinking beyond annual fundraising. Planned gifts are typically larger-than-average donations and cost significantly less to secure than traditional fundraising methods. In times when government or institutional support may shrink, having a pipeline of future gifts can be the difference between surviving and thriving.

üí° According to Giving USA, every $1 invested in planned giving brings in nearly $57 in return.

Plus, building a legacy program isn't just about fundraising‚Äîit's about deepening donor relationships. These are the supporters who care deeply about your mission and want to see it endure well into the future.

 

How to Start a Planned Giving Conversation with Your Donors

The beauty of planned giving is that it taps into something timeless: legacy. Your most loyal supporters already believe in your work. Helping them understand they can leave a lasting impact‚Äîeven beyond their lifetime‚Äîopens an empowering door for them.

Here‚Äôs how to begin:

  • Identify your champions: Long-time donors, board members, and volunteers are often your best prospects for legacy giving.
  • Normalize the conversation: Add simple language to your donor communications: ‚ÄúHave you considered including [Your Organization] in your estate plan?‚Äù
  • Share stories of impact: If you‚Äôve received a planned gift, share that story. If not, highlight a hypothetical example or testimonial from a donor who has made that decision elsewhere.

This doesn‚Äôt have to be a complex or uncomfortable conversation. In fact, many donors appreciate being asked and are looking for ways to make meaningful, lasting contributions‚Äîespecially in times when the future feels more fragile.

 

Truman Heartland is Here to Help

You don‚Äôt have to launch your planned giving program alone. At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we work closely with nonprofits across the region to make planned giving simple‚Äîfor both the organization and the donor.

Through tools like charitable funds, donor education, and expert guidance, we help your supporters structure gifts that align with their values and ensure long-term support for your mission. Just like the Hope House, the Jackson County Historical Society, and other partners, you can begin building a legacy that withstands change and uncertainty.

 

Ready to Start Your Planned Giving Journey?

If recent headlines have left you thinking more seriously about financial resilience, you‚Äôre not alone. Building a pipeline of planned gifts can offer peace of mind‚Äîfor you, your board, and your community.

title: Lower Your Taxes, Boost Your Giving: The Power of QCDs
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
If you're 70¬Ω or older and have a traditional IRA, there's a tax-savvy giving strategy you should know about: the Qualified Charitable Distribution (QCD). It‚Äôs one of the most powerful tools available to support the causes you care about‚Äîwhile reducing your taxable income.

In other words: QCDs let you give more, pay less, and make an immediate impact in your community.

 

What‚Äôs a QCD‚Äîand Why Should You Care?

A Qualified Charitable Distribution allows individuals aged 70¬Ω or older to transfer up to $108,000 per year directly from their IRA to qualified charities, like the Truman Heartland Community Foundation or a fund you‚Äôve established here. Each year, the maximum distribution amount is updated in proportion to inflation. 

Because the money goes directly to charity, it doesn‚Äôt count as taxable income‚Äîwhich can help reduce your adjusted gross income (AGI), potentially lowering your Medicare premiums and minimizing the tax on Social Security benefits.

Starting at age 73, the IRS requires you to take minimum distributions from your IRA each year (known as RMDs). If you don‚Äôt need those funds, a QCD can satisfy your RMD tax-free while supporting nonprofits that matter to you.

Key Benefits of Giving Through a QCD

 QCDs offer tax advantages even if you take the standard deduction.

‚úÖ Lower your taxable income
 Reducing your AGI can have ripple effects, especially for retirees.

‚úÖ Meet your RMD while giving back
 A smart way to fulfill IRS requirements and support your favorite causes.

‚úÖ Immediate local impact
 QCDs fuel the work of nonprofits right now‚Äîwhen they need it most.

 

Who Should Consider a QCD?

  • You‚Äôre 70¬Ω or older with a traditional IRA
  • You‚Äôre taking‚Äîor preparing to take‚ÄîRequired Minimum Distributions
  • You want to give back without increasing your tax burden
  • You support multiple nonprofits and want a simple, efficient giving strategy

If this sounds like you, a QCD could be a smart next step.

 

How Truman Heartland Can Help

Making a QCD is easier than you think‚Äîespecially when you work with Truman Heartland. We can help you direct your gift to a nonprofit of your choice, or even set up a Designated Fund or Scholarship Fund to focus your giving where it matters most.

Please note: While QCDs cannot be made to donor-advised funds, there are many other types of funds at Truman Heartland that do qualify.

Our team is here to help you navigate your options and ensure your giving is both strategic and meaningful.

 

Now is the Time for Smart Giving

QCDs are a win-win‚Äîlower taxes for you, and stronger support for nonprofits in your community. As we all navigate a complex economic and political environment, being intentional about how and when you give can make a big difference.

If you‚Äôre ready to explore your options or have questions about how to get started, we‚Äôre here to help.

title: Katie Ameku: A 2025 Rhodes Scholar Empowered by her Community
author: Melanie Adkins
body:
At Truman Heartland Community Foundation (THCF), we have the privilege of supporting some of the most talented and driven students in our community.

Our donors invest in young people who are passionate about learning, leading, and making a difference. But every now and then, a student‚Äôs journey stands out as an extraordinary testament to the power of education, opportunity, and generosity.

Today, we celebrate Katie Ameku, an Independence, Missouri native, and one of just 32 students in the United States selected as a 2025 Rhodes Scholar‚Äîone of the most prestigious academic honors in the world. This remarkable achievement will allow her to study at the University of Oxford in 2025, where she plans to focus on Philosophy, Politics, and Economics.

While Katie‚Äôs hard work and brilliance are what got her there, her ability to access competitive academic opportunities along the way was made possible in part by the generosity of Truman Heartland donors.

 

Investing in Education: The Power of Scholarships

Katie received $27,750 in scholarships from Truman Heartland Community Foundation between 2021 and 2024, including awards from:

  • The Gene and Joanne Cable Scholarship Fund
  • The Sam and Lindsey Porter Scholarship Fund
  • The Norman and Mary Anne Davidson Scholarship Fund

For many students, summers are spent working to cover the cost of tuition. But thanks to these scholarships from Truman Heartland donors, Katie was able to use her summers to pursue advanced research opportunities instead‚Äîexperiences that set her apart as a top candidate for the Rhodes Scholarship.

She conducted research at Georgia Tech and the University of Pennsylvania, gaining hands-on experience in X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy and computational material science. These summer research opportunities expanded her knowledge, helped her connect with leading scholars in her field, and made her more competitive at a national level.

"The scholarships I received from Truman Heartland allowed me to pursue opportunities I never imagined," Katie shared. "Instead of staying back to work, I was able to spend my summers expanding my research, working with amazing academic leaders, and preparing myself for the future. These experiences were truly life-changing, and I am incredibly thankful for the generosity of those who made them possible."

 

A Scholar, A Leader, A Public Servant

Katie is not only an accomplished scientist but also a dedicated leader and public servant.

She served as Associate Zone Councilor for the Society of Physics Students, representing five Midwestern states, and has a deep passion for numismatics, specifically researching currencies used in Japanese American Internment Camps.

Beyond academics, she has also been active in public service, serving on both the Jackson County Democratic Committee and the Missouri Democratic State Committee, where she is the youngest member. Her interest in science policy and communication will play a crucial role in her future studies at Oxford.

But no matter where her education takes her, Katie remains deeply connected to her hometown of Independence. She hopes that the skills and experiences she gains abroad will allow her to one day return and make meaningful contributions to her community. Her drive to use her education for the betterment of others is exactly the kind of impact Truman Heartland scholarships aim to support.

 

A Message to Our Donors: Your Support Changes Lives

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we know that scholarships alone do not create success‚Äîstudents like Katie achieve greatness through talent, determination, and relentless hard work.

However, what your generosity does is remove barriers. It ensures that students have the freedom to pursue the best academic opportunities and reach their full potential.

Katie‚Äôs story is not just a personal victory‚Äîit is a success story for everyone who has ever contributed to a scholarship fund at Truman Heartland.

 

Looking Ahead: The Next Generation of Scholars

As Katie prepares to begin her studies at Oxford University in 2025, we at Truman Heartland Community Foundation celebrate not just her remarkable achievements, but also the donors who made her journey possible.

To all who have contributed to a scholarship fund, please know that your generosity matters. It creates life-changing opportunities for students like Katie, helping them compete on the national stage and take their education to the highest level.

We invite you to continue supporting the next generation of leaders, innovators, and changemakers.

 

Join Us in Supporting the Future

If you would like to be part of a student‚Äôs success story, consider contributing to a Truman Heartland scholarship fund. Your support could help launch the next Rhodes Scholar, scientist, educator, or leader.

For more information about our scholarship program and how you can help, visit THCF‚Äôs Scholarship Directory.

title: Giving Smart: Maximize Your Charitable Impact with Donor Advised Funds in 2025
author: Cole Eason JD
body:
As a generous donor, you want to make the most of your charitable giving while also optimizing your tax benefits. With the 2025 standard deduction increasing to $15,000 for individuals and $30,000 for married couples, many donors find they no longer receive additional tax benefits when giving to charity.

However, by using a Donor Advised Fund (DAF) and a tax-smart strategy called charitable bunching, you can maximize your deductions and make an even greater impact with your giving.

What Is Charitable Bunching?

Charitable bunching is a strategy where donors "bunch" multiple years‚Äô worth of contributions into a single tax year to exceed the standard deduction and qualify for itemized deductions.

Rather than donating the same amount every year, you can contribute a larger amount every third year to a Donor Advised Fund (DAF). This allows you to itemize your deductions in the contribution year while taking the standard deduction in the off-years.

How Does It Work?

Let‚Äôs say a married couple typically donates $10,000 annually to charity. Under normal tax rules, their deductions might not exceed the new standard deduction of $30,000, so their giving provides no additional tax benefit.

Instead, using a charitable bunching strategy, they can:

  • Triple their donation in a single year, contributing $30,000 to a DAF
  • Itemize their deductions that year, significantly lowering taxable income
  • Continue to support their favorite charities through grants from their DAF
  • Take the standard deduction the next 2 tax years until its time to replenish their DAF

Tax Benefits of Charitable Bunching

‚úÖ Increase Your Tax Deductions ‚Äì Every third year, you can itemize and maximize your tax savings.

‚úÖ Maintain Steady Giving ‚Äì Your favorite charities continue receiving support each year.

‚úÖ Maximize Tax-Free Growth ‚Äì Funds in a DAF can be invested and potentially grow, increasing your giving power.

‚úÖ Simplify Record-Keeping ‚Äì Instead of tracking multiple small donations, you handle one major donation every few years.

For example, under the bunching strategy, donors using a DAF received $18,000 in additional tax deductions every third year‚Äîa significant financial advantage.

Who Should Consider Charitable Bunching?

You may benefit from this strategy if you:

  • Typically donate a significant amount annually
  • Have itemized deductions that are near or below the standard deduction
  • Want to maximize tax savings while continuing to support charities long-term

Start Giving Smarter Today

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we help donors strategically maximize their charitable giving through Donor Advised Funds and charitable bunching. Learn more details with our Printable Charitable Bunching Guide.

Want to learn how a DAF can work for you? Contact Cole Eason, Vice President of Advancement, at 816.912.4182 or eason@thcf.org for a consultation.

title: Leaving a Legacy: How IRA Beneficiary Designations Can Maximize Tax Benefits for Your Heirs
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
For many, leaving a legacy means more than passing down wealth‚Äîit‚Äôs about making a lasting impact on family and the causes that matter most. One of the most tax-efficient ways to do this is through careful IRA beneficiary planning.

If your IRA or retirement account is a significant part of your estate, it‚Äôs important to understand how the SECURE Act and tax laws impact your heirs, and which charitable strategies can help protect your them from unnecessary tax burdens while supporting the causes you care about.

The Power of IRA Beneficiary Designations

One of the simplest ways to leave a tax-efficient legacy is by naming beneficiaries on your IRA or retirement accounts. Unlike other assets that pass-through probate, IRAs transfer directly to named beneficiaries, avoiding delays.

However, not all beneficiaries receive equal tax treatment. Since the passage of the SECURE Act, many heirs now face a 10-year payout rule that can significantly increase their tax burden.

The SECURE Act and How It Affects Inherited IRAs

Before the SECURE Act, an heir who inherited an IRA could take Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) over their lifetime, spreading out taxable withdrawals and reducing their annual tax liability.

Now, the SECURE Act requires most non-spouse beneficiaries to withdraw the full balance of the inherited IRA within 10 years of the account holder‚Äôs passing.

Why Is This a Problem?

  1. Larger Tax Burdens for Heirs ‚Äì Instead of spreading distributions over decades, heirs must now withdraw (and pay taxes on) the entire IRA within 10 years. If the inheritance pushes them into a higher tax bracket, they could pay significantly more in taxes.
  2. Less Control Over the Timing of Withdrawals ‚Äì Heirs can no longer stretch withdrawals over their lifetime to minimize taxable income.
  3. Reduced Wealth Transfer Efficiency ‚Äì More of the IRA is lost to taxes instead of benefiting your heirs or charitable causes.

This change has many high-net-worth individuals rethinking their estate plans‚Äîand for good reason.

Why Designating a Charity as an IRA Beneficiary Makes Sense

Another highly effective legacy strategy is to leave IRA assets to charity while leaving other assets (such as real estate or taxable brokerage accounts) to family

Why? Because charities don‚Äôt pay income taxes.

  • If heirs inherit an IRA, they must pay ordinary income tax on distributions.
  • If a charity inherits the IRA, 100% of the funds can be used for its mission tax-free.
  • Heirs can inherit other step-up-in-basis assets (like stocks or real estate), which can be passed down with minimal tax consequences.

We often find that donors want to support multiple charities through their IRA. This can be done easily through a Donor Advised Fund, which is well-equipped to support multiple charities. 

Smart planning can help ensure that the wealth you worked hard to build is used efficiently‚Äîwhether supporting family, charity, or both.

With proper planning, your legacy can extend far beyond your lifetime, ensuring that both your family and the causes you care about continue to thrive.

Get Started on Your Legacy Plan Today

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we help donors create customized charitable giving strategies that maximize tax benefits while making a lasting difference. Whether you‚Äôre considering a Donor-Advised Fund or a direct IRA beneficiary designation, we can help guide you through the best options.

title: Gene and Joanne Cable: A Legacy of Thoughtful Giving and Lasting Impact
author: Melanie Adkins
body:
Philanthropy is more than generosity‚Äîit‚Äôs about vision, strategy, and leaving a meaningful legacy. Few exemplify this better than Gene and Joanne Cable, whose impact can be seen across education, healthcare, the arts, and community development.

Their story isn‚Äôt just one of giving, but of thoughtful, strategic philanthropy that has created lasting change in Kansas City and beyond.

While their support extended to many organizations, Truman Heartland Community Foundation (THCF) played a vital role in helping them manage, grow, and maximize their charitable impact. By utilizing a range of philanthropic tools, they built a legacy that continues to benefit future generations.

This year, as we reflect on the many donors who have shaped our community, we take a special moment to honor Joanne Cable, who passed in 2024, and Gene Cable, who passed away in 2022. Their legacy, built over decades of giving, is a testament to the power of philanthropy done with intention, care, and heart. While they are no longer with us, the impact of their generosity continues through the scholarships, endowments, and community investments they so thoughtfully created.

A Life of Hard Work and Purposeful Giving

Gene Cable built an automotive empire in Kansas City, founding what would become Cable Dahmer Chevrolet, one of the region‚Äôs most successful dealerships. But success in business was only part of his story. He and Joanne believed wealth should be used to lift others up‚Äîa value they carried throughout their 72-year marriage.

They never limited themselves to one cause. Their giving evolved over time, spanning scholarships, healthcare investments, arts funding, and community support. Joanne, deeply involved in local philanthropy, served as a docent at the Truman Library, and played a leadership role in the Junior Service League. Gene, equally committed, never forgot his humble beginnings on a farm in northern Missouri, giving back to Gilman City High School through their FFA chapter. 

Strategic Giving Through Truman Heartland

In 1998, the Cables established a Donor Advised Fund (DAF) at Truman Heartland, recognizing the value of having a trusted partner to help manage their giving. Over the years, THCF helped them identify opportunities, facilitate grants, and ensure their gifts had maximum impact.

One of their greatest passions was education. In 2011, they established the Gene and Joanne Cable Scholarship, supporting graduating seniors from Truman, William Chrisman, and Van Horn High Schools. Understanding the financial burdens students face, they also provided ongoing scholarship renewals to help recipients complete their degrees. Their commitment to education extended to Longview Community College, where they funded automotive scholarships to support students entering the trade industry.

But their giving was never limited to just one approach. They used Truman Heartland to facilitate grants, create endowments, and support urgent community needs. Joanne particularly valued how THCF could connect them with causes they might not have known about, allowing them to make both large-scale contributions and smaller, targeted gifts that filled critical funding gaps.

Beyond Truman Heartland: A Wide-Ranging Philanthropic Vision

While Truman Heartland was an important partner, the Cables‚Äô generosity spanned far beyond a single foundation. They personally invested in healthcare, the arts, and community spaces, ensuring that their giving touched every corner of the region.

  • Children‚Äôs Healthcare: Their donations helped bring cutting-edge medical equipment to Eastern Jackson County. They funded an MRI machine for Children‚Äôs Mercy East Hospital, and contributed a 3D medical printer to St. Luke‚Äôs Cardiatric Center Hospital. Additionally, they created an endowment at Children‚Äôs Mercy East to support nursing students.
  • The Arts & Music Education: Joanne was a board member at the Music/Arts Institute in Independence, where the Cables funded scholarships for students and improvements to the building. Additionally, they gave a scholarship to a young man who went through the entirety of the program. When Joanne passed, he attended and played music at her memorial service, and the family was very touched by his performance.  
  • Community Infrastructure: They didn‚Äôt just donate to organizations‚Äîthey built lasting structures. One of their landmark contributions was funding the construction of a home, on the Drumm Farm Campus to house foster parents and their children.  They also gifted a water fountain to Powell Gardens, creating a serene gathering space for visitors.
  • Community Development: Gene was active in the Independence Rotary club all throughout his career. He made contributions to their community projects that helped the CSL, City of Independence and Hope House. He was instrumental in the 1960s and 70‚Äôs in putting together the charter for the City of Independence.  

 

A Family Legacy That Lives On

For Gene and Joanne, philanthropy wasn‚Äôt just about writing checks‚Äîit was about instilling a deep sense of responsibility in their family. Their daughter, Cindy Cavanah, continued to pursue her own lifestyle of philanthropy and giving back to communities. She has served on the board of Truman Heartland Foundation for 9 years, and the Drumm Farm Center for Children for 20 years, as well as on the Independence Chamber Board. She continues to manage their endowments at Truman Heartland, ensuring that their legacy of giving endures.

Their mindset every day was focused on generosity, shaping a legacy that is still being written. Through endowments, scholarships, and strategic investments, the Cables have ensured that their wealth will continue to benefit Kansas City for generations to come.

An Inspiration for Future Philanthropists

Not everyone has the level of resources the Cables did. But their story isn‚Äôt just about the amount they gave‚Äîit‚Äôs about the way they gave. They used Truman Heartland‚Äôs tools to make strategic, high-impact donations while also ensuring personal, heartfelt contributions to the causes they cared about most.

For those looking to leave their own mark, the Cables provide an inspiring example:

‚úÖ Start with passion‚Äîfind the causes that matter most to you.

‚úÖ Use strategic giving tools‚Äîpartner with organizations like THCF to grow your impact.

‚úÖ Think long-term‚Äîconsider endowments and scholarships to create a lasting legacy.

Though Gene and Joanne are no longer with us, their generosity continues changing lives every day. Their impact is not just measured in dollars, but in the students they empowered, the families they uplifted, and the community they strengthened. Their story serves as a reminder that philanthropy, when done with purpose, can truly shape the future.

title: The Power of Endowed Funds in our Region
author: Phil Hanson MPA CAP¬Æ
body:
Endowed funds will generate $440,000 in grant funds awarded this year.

It's Competitive Grants Season at Truman Heartland Community Foundation. This is the time of year that reminds us of the power of endowed funds created by charitable people who want to make a positive impact on their community.

This year, we will have approximately $300,000 available to award for Community Grants and $140,000 for the Jelley Children's Education grants, approximately $440,000 in total. 

There are 23 endowments that provide funds for our competitive grants process, and most were created through generous gifts that community members made through their estate to create endowed funds to support charitable organizations. 

At Truman Heartland, we specialize in helping fundholders shape an endowment that serves their particular interest. 

Some of these endowed funds are focused on a particular type of charity that the donor seeks to support. We refer to these as a field of interest funds and, for instance, have the Marge Pollard Hospice Fund, which supports hospice care. 

Others are focused on a particular geographic area, like the J.D. Browning Endowment that supports organizations in Lee‚Äôs Summit. 

Other endowments can be utilized more broadly and are not focused on a particular interest of the donor. A good example is the Willa Fancher and Martha Taggart Endowment, created in November 2020 with an estate gift of $2.8 Million.  This endowed fund, in just 4 years, has made grants of $502,000 to charities in our community while the balance of the fund due to investment returns has grown to $3.3 Million.  It‚Äôs a great example of how an endowed fund works. 

The board of Truman Heartland Community Foundation is charged with managing these endowed funds and ensuring we are using them as the donor instructed so that the spirit of their giving is honored, even as organizations evolve or change throughout the years. 

By working with a Community Foundation donors can be confident that grants from their endowment will be supporting the organizations making an impact in our community today as well as 20 years from now. It‚Äôs our privilege to work with many charitable individuals in our community to create and serve their legacy. 

Urge Your Nonprofit Neighbors to Apply for our Grants

We have two grant application processes: The Jelley Family Foundation Endowment for Children‚Äôs Education, with $140,000 available, applications due March 10.  The Community Grants, with $300,000 available, and applications due March 24. 

If you know of Nonprofits serving the Eastern Jackson County and Cass County area, please encourage them to apply by going to https://www.thcf.org/grant-seekers for more information.

title: Building a Lasting Legacy: The Power of Establishing an Endowed Fund
author: Cole Eason JD
body:
When you think about the impact you want to make in your community, do you envision something that lasts just for today‚Äîor something that will continue to make a difference for generations to come?

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation (THCF), we help generous individuals, families, and businesses turn their passion for giving into a lasting legacy through endowed funds. By establishing an endowed fund, you create a permanent charitable resource that grows over time and provides ongoing support to the causes that matter most to you.

Best of all, we make the process simple, meaningful, and deeply personal. You can choose a Field of Interest Fund‚Äîallowing your endowment to always serve a specific cause or area of interest that aligns with your values. Whether you care about education, health, the arts, animal welfare, or community betterment, an endowed fund ensures that your generosity will continue to make an impact for generations to come.

 

What is an Endowed Fund?

An endowed fund is a permanent charitable fund where the principal gift is invested and grows over time. Instead of being spent all at once, the fund generates income that is used annually to award grants to nonprofits working in your chosen area of interest.

This means that while your initial gift remains untouched, it keeps giving year after year‚Äîproviding sustainable funding for the causes you care about long into the future.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Engage Future Generations ‚Äì Many donors establish endowed funds as a way to involve their children and grandchildren in philanthropy, creating a family legacy of giving.

title: Maximizing Your Donor-Advised Fund
author: Cole Eason JD
body:
Donor-Advised Funds (DAFs) have become one of the most popular ways to manage charitable giving. With their tax advantages, flexibility, and potential for long-term growth, they offer a convenient way to support the causes you care about.

But while setting up a DAF is easier than ever‚Äîoften through national financial institutions‚Äîit‚Äôs important to ask yourself:

üëâ Where is my money really going?
üëâ Is it making the biggest impact possible?
üëâ Does it reflect my values and the needs of my community?

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we believe philanthropy should be personal, strategic, and rooted in the communities we call home. 

While national DAF providers can offer convenience, they often lack the local expertise, relationships, and hands-on support that help donors create a meaningful and lasting impact.

 

The Growing Popularity of Donor-Advised Funds

DAFs are reshaping the culture of philanthropy. With over $250 billion in assets held in these funds nationwide, they provide a powerful way for donors to organize their giving, support multiple charities, and take advantage of tax benefits.

However, many donors don‚Äôt realize that their charitable dollars‚Äîwhen managed by a national DAF provider‚Äîmay not necessarily benefit the causes or communities closest to their hearts. Instead, funds may remain undistributed for long periods, or they may go to large, well-known national charities rather than addressing critical local needs.

That‚Äôs where a community foundation makes all the difference.

 

Why Work with a Community Foundation for Your DAF?

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we offer a more thoughtful and connected approach to philanthropy. Here‚Äôs how we help our donors make the most of their charitable giving:

1. Deep Local Knowledge for a Greater Impact

When you work with a community foundation, you gain access to trusted experts who understand the most pressing needs in your area. Unlike national DAF providers, we are on the ground, working closely with local nonprofits, civic leaders, and organizations that create real, measurable change.

Instead of simply distributing grants at random, we help connect your passion with purpose, ensuring that your generosity supports causes that align with your values and create meaningful, lasting impact in your own backyard.

2. Personalized, Hands-On Philanthropic Support

A national DAF provider may offer a platform to manage donations, but they lack the personal touch that makes giving truly rewarding. At Truman Heartland, we provide:

  • Personalized philanthropic advising ‚Äì We help you create a strategic giving plan based on your goals and interests.
  • Grantmaking support ‚Äì Need guidance on the best local organizations to support? We do the research for you.
  • Legacy planning ‚Äì Whether you want to involve future generations in philanthropy or establish an ongoing charitable legacy, we offer expert guidance to ensure your vision lives on.

3. Keeping Your Charitable Dollars in Your Community

A major drawback of national DAF providers is that your funds could be distributed anywhere in the country‚Äîeven to causes that don‚Äôt directly impact your community.

At Truman Heartland, we ensure that your generosity stays local, supporting the organizations and initiatives that strengthen the place you call home. When you choose a community foundation, you‚Äôre not just giving‚Äîyou‚Äôre investing in your community‚Äôs future.

4. Responsiveness in Times of Crisis

One of the biggest benefits of partnering with a community foundation is our ability to respond quickly when unexpected needs arise. Whether it‚Äôs a natural disaster, economic downturn, or urgent social issue, we mobilize resources immediately, ensuring that help reaches those who need it most.

With a national provider, your funds may sit in an account for years, waiting to be distributed. But at Truman Heartland, we believe in taking action when it matters most.

5. All the Benefits of a National DAF‚ÄîWith a Local, Mission-Driven Focus

Working with Truman Heartland gives you the same tax benefits, investment growth potential, and flexibility as a national provider‚Äîwhile also ensuring that your funds are actively making a difference in your community.

You can still contribute a variety of assets, including:
‚úÖ Cash and appreciated stock
‚úÖ Real estate and business interests
‚úÖ Retirement assets and life insurance

But instead of your funds sitting untouched in a large financial institution, they will be strategically distributed to create meaningful change in the areas you care about most.

 

Making the Most of Your Donor-Advised Fund

As DAFs continue to grow in popularity, they are becoming a mainstream giving tool, much like retirement or college savings accounts. But simply having a DAF isn‚Äôt enough‚Äîthe real power lies in how you use it.

By partnering with Truman Heartland Community Foundation, you ensure your giving is strategic, impactful, and deeply connected to your community.

If you already have a DAF with a national provider, it‚Äôs never too late to explore ways to maximize its impact locally. We can help you:


‚úî Transfer your existing DAF to Truman Heartland
‚úî Identify high-impact giving opportunities
‚úî Ensure that your philanthropy aligns with your values and goals

Let‚Äôs Make a Difference Together

At Truman Heartland Community Foundation, we believe in thoughtful, community-driven philanthropy. When you choose to work with us, you‚Äôre choosing a future where your generosity directly improves lives in your community.

If you‚Äôd like to learn more about how we can help you make the most of your Donor-Advised Fund, reach out today. Together, we can create a smarter, more impactful approach to giving‚Äîone that keeps your charitable dollars working for the people and places you care about most.

title: Record Breaking Generosity Brings Hope for 2025
author: Phil Hanson MPA CAP¬Æ
body:
At your Community Foundation for Eastern Jackson County and beyond, (Truman Heartland Community Foundation) we have many highlights to celebrate from 2024, made possible by the generosity of our fundholders.

As we begin a new year it‚Äôs a great time to reflect on milestones from this year in charitable giving and think about our goals and hopes for the coming year. 

At your Community Foundation for Eastern Jackson County (Truman Heartland Community Foundation) we have many highlights to celebrate from 2024, made possible by the generosity of our fundholders.

The growth of charitable contributions within our foundation has set records in several important categories, including Grants, Scholarships, Donor Advised Fund contributions, and legacy building.

GRANTS & SCHOLARSHIPS:

We set another record for total number of grants distributed to hundreds of nonprofit organizations and student scholarships in our community. The total in 2024 is $9 million compared to $7.3 million in 2023; an increase of 23%. 

An important portion of this total is scholarships which set a new record of $828,000 in 2024. These scholarships from 173 scholarship funds will enhance the education opportunities of the 334 students who received scholarships. 

The total amount is an increase of 70% in scholarships compared to the total in 2020. All of this has been made possible by the generosity of people in our community who have a passion for education and compassion for those who can use some support to achieve their educational dreams. 

DONOR ADVISED FUNDS:

Our Donor Advised Fundholders continue to set records making generous grants from their funds to their favorite charities. Grants from these 320 funds totaled $4.5 million in 2024 compared to $3.1 million in 2023, an increase of 45%. 

More than 1,800 separate grants were made from these Donor Advised Funds, and every one of them tells a story about the passion a fundholder has for a nonprofit and their compassion for those served by the organization. 

We are pleased that we added 43 new funds in 2024 and welcome these new members to our foundation family. 

BUILDING LEGACIES:

We also had 14 families join our Heartland Legacy Society by including their fund at the Foundation in their estate plans. It‚Äôs our pleasure to work with these families (now totaling 204) to enable them to leave a legacy through their charitable giving.

title: Mary K. Axtell Trust Scholarship Available for  Students in Carroll and Ray Counties
author: Rachael Cassiday Watkins MFA
body:
The Mary K. Axtell Trust Scholarship provides up to $5,000 per academic year for graduating high school seniors or past graduates from public high schools serving residents of Carroll and Ray Counties.

Truman Heartland Community Foundation invitArticle Content es students from Carroll and Ray Counties to apply for the Mary K. Axtell Trust Scholarship for the 2025-2026 school year. The due date for applications is February 14, 2025. The application can be found here: https://www.thcf.org/scholarships/mary-k-axtell-trust-scholarship. For the 2024-2025 school year, the Mary K. Axtell Trust Scholarship awarded 32 students a total of $160,000. 

 

The Mary K. Axtell Trust Scholarship provides up to $5,000 per academic year for graduating high school seniors or past graduates from public high schools serving residents of Carroll and Ray Counties and can be renewed for up to three additional years. Applicants must be pursuing an undergraduate degree at an accredited junior college, college, or university or a certification from an accredited technical school. Preference may be given to students pursuing agriculture-related degrees. 

 

Students can apply now using Truman Heartland‚Äôs general scholarship application. The general scholarship application is a two-step process: students complete a standard application with details about themselves and their educational aspirations, and then the scholarship portal matches them to all the scholarships for which they are eligible and directs them to complete the specific requirements for each scholarship. 

 

For the Axtell Scholarship, the specific requirements are transcripts including final grades from the Fall 2024 semester, a 500-word personal essay about the students‚Äô interests, accomplishments, and educational goals, and a letter of recommendation from a supervisor of an activity in which the student participates.

 

Students renewing their past Axtell Scholarships should complete the general application and indicate that they wish to renew their Axtell Scholarship when prompted. 

 

Mary Katherine (Bush) Axtell was the daughter of Saline County cattleman and farmer Pike Caleb Bush and Pauline Metod Jones Bush. Early settlers in Missouri, the Bush family had a large stock ranch and farms in Carroll County near Norborne, Missouri, a Wood Heights farm in Ray County and a ranch in Jeff Davis County, Texas near Valentine. Mary, the second of three children, inherited parcels of the family farms when her parents passed away.

 

Mary passed away in 1960, and when the Bush family farms were sold, Blue Ridge Bank and Trust Co., the administrators of the Axtell Trust, established a scholarship fund with Truman Heartland Community Foundation in 2019. As instructed in Mary‚Äôs charitable will and testamentary trust, the scholarship will provide perpetual support for students of Ray and Carroll County. 

 

Phil Hanson, Truman Heartland‚Äôs President and CEO, said, ‚ÄúWe are honored to carry on Mary Axtell‚Äôs legacy and offer students in Ray and Carroll County the opportunity to continue their education.‚Äù  

 

In 2024, Truman Heartland awarded more than $828,000 in 461 scholarship awards to nearly 340 local students. More than 250 scholarships are currently available for students pursuing undergraduate, graduate, and technical degrees. Visit https://www.thcf.org/Scholarships to learn more and begin the application process. For questions or assistance with scholarships, please contact Rachael Cassiday Watkins at watkins@thcf.org or 816-912-4185.

title: Using a Charitable Remainder Trust with a Donor Advised Fund
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
A Charitable Remainder Trust (CRT) combined with a Donor-Advised Fund (DAF) offers a strategic approach to philanthropy, providing both financial benefits and flexibility for donors.

Here's how this combination works:

Charitable Remainder Trust (CRT)

A CRT is an irrevocable trust that provides income to the donor or other beneficiaries for a specified period, either for life or a set number of years, with the remainder of the assets going to a designated charity at the end of the term. The key benefits of a CRT include:

  • Income Stream: The trust generates regular income payments to the donor or beneficiaries, which can be structured as either a fixed annuity (CRAT) or a percentage of the trust's assets (CRUT).
  • Tax Advantages: Donors receive an immediate charitable income tax deduction and avoid capital gains taxes on appreciated assets transferred to the trust.
  • Estate Planning: Assets in the CRT are excluded from the donor's estate, potentially reducing estate taxes.

Donor-Advised Fund (DAF)

  • A DAF acts as a charitable investment account for supporting organizations donors care about. When combined with a CRT, it provides additional flexibility:
  • Remainder Beneficiary: Naming a DAF as the remainder beneficiary of a CRT allows donors to defer deciding on specific charities until later, offering adaptability in philanthropic goals.
  • Ongoing Family Involvement: Donors' families can continue to recommend grants from the DAF, maintaining involvement in charitable decisions over time.
  • Investment Management: The donor's financial advisor can continue to manage the investments within the DAF, ensuring consistent oversight and strategic growth of assets.

Strategic Benefits

By coupling a CRT with a DAF, donors gain significant control over their charitable giving. This combination allows them to enjoy lifetime income benefits while planning substantial future gifts. It also simplifies adjustments to charitable designations without costly legal amendments, making it an attractive option for those seeking both financial security and philanthropic impact.

title: Why is Year-End Giving Important to Nonprofits?
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
Nonprofit organizations in the United States typically receive a significant portion of their annual contributions during the last two months of the year.

While exact percentages can vary among organizations, it's common for nonprofits to collect between 30% and 40% of their total annual donations during November and December. This surge is often attributed to year-end giving campaigns, holiday generosity, and tax considerations. It is the perfect time of year where an agency‚Äôs needs and donor‚Äôs needs meet, making a huge impact. 

Tax Deductions for Donors: Many donors choose to make charitable contributions at the end of the year to take advantage of tax deductions. In the U.S., donations made by December 31st are eligible for that year‚Äôs tax returns. This incentivizes donors to give more during the final months of the year, boosting nonprofit revenue.

It‚Äôs a perfect time for an IRA Charitable Rollover: Older adults can donate directly from their IRAs, which can count as a required minimum distribution, offering tax advantages while benefiting a cause they care about.

The Holiday Spirit: People tend to feel more generous around the holidays, especially as the year draws to a close. There's often a cultural push toward giving, whether it's through gifts, charity drives, or end-of-year campaigns. Nonprofits capitalize on this spirit by running end-of-year fundraising campaigns. Remember, many organizations or corporations match their employees‚Äô charitable contributions, and a year-end campaign is the prime time for donors to maximize their giving opportunities and give back more to the charities they care about.

Tis the season to meet goals and plan for the future: Nonprofits often have annual financial goals to meet, and year-end giving helps them close the gap between their funding needs and actual contributions. For many organizations, the last quarter of the year can provide the bulk of their funding for the entire year.

Year-end gifts help nonprofits maintain their programs, plan for the upcoming year, and cover operational expenses. This is especially important for smaller nonprofits that rely heavily on individual donations.

Answering holiday wishes: You, as a donor, can make wishes come true. Donors are motivated to give more generously when they know their contribution can meet a critical need or a time-sensitive opportunity.

For many nonprofits, year-end giving is an essential part of their fundraising strategy, helping them not only to meet financial goals for the year but also to build momentum for the year ahead. It offers nonprofits a chance to connect with donors, celebrate the impact of their work, and create lasting relationships that support their mission, programs, and services.

title: 2024 Year-End Giving Deadlines
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
As we approach the end of the year, it's a wonderful time to reflect on the joy of giving and making a positive impact.

With that in mind, here are some key dates and recommended strategies for maximizing the impact of your year-end donations. 

  • If you're planning to donate gifts of appreciated stock or securities, it's recommended that you initiate the transfer by December 20, 2024. It's best to notify your Professional Advisor of the transfer as soon as possible, as the request may take several days to process.
  • If you plan to send checks via postal mail or carriers such as FedEx, UPS, or DHL, they must be postmarked on or before December 31, 2024.
  • The charities you choose must receive Qualified Charitable Distributions (QCDs) from your IRA by December 31, 2024. It is highly recommended that you start the process early!
  • If you're planning to make wire transfers of cash, they must be initiated by December 23, 2024.
  • Credit card gifts can be made by phone or online until December 31, 2024.
  • If you are a THCF fundholder and want to make year-end grant recommendations, please do so in your Donor Portal by noon on December 10, 2024. Making your designations by this date will ensure enough time for the Foundation staff to process your request and get your donation checks mailed before the end of the year.
  • THCF accepts various assets, including cash, stocks, real estate, or other appreciated assets. If you have a unique asset or have any questions about the timing of your donations, feel free to reach out to our Vice-President of Advancement, Cole Eason, who would be happy to help guide you based on your situation and goals.

November is the perfect time to reflect on the positive impact we all can make in our communities. Remember, every little bit counts, and your contributions at year-end can make a significant difference in the lives of individuals and families throughout the region. By partnering with Truman Heartland Community Foundation for your year-end giving, you can take an active role in supporting the causes you care about most.

Let's make this holiday season a time of giving, gratitude, and generosity!

title: National Philanthropy Day
author: Truman Heartland Community Foundation
body:
It's that time of year again when we celebrate the incredible spirit of giving and kindness‚ÄîNational Philanthropy Day (NPD)!

This special day recognizes the power of philanthropy and the amazing individuals and organizations that are changing the world for the better. 

Philanthropist and attorney Doug Freeman inspired the idea of National Philanthropy Day. After five years of work and hundreds of letters, the idea gained support nationwide. In 1986, President Ronald Reagan proclaimed November 15 as National Philanthropy Day. From then on, NPD has been a time for us to come together and celebrate the remarkable impact philanthropy has on our communities. 

So many of our fundholders, volunteers, and supporters practice philanthropy in so many ways. Here are some ideas that you might consider this November 15:

  1. Gather your friends for a fun-filled day of volunteering. Whether helping out at a local food pantry, organizing a neighborhood cleanup, or lending a hand at the local animal shelter, your time and effort can make a world of difference. 
  2. Giving doesn't always mean opening up your wallet. You can make a huge impact by donating stuff. Consider dropping off non-perishable food items at a local food bank, donating good-quality clothes to a charity, or contributing essentials to a shelter. Every little bit helps! 
  3. Educate yourself about the current needs in your community and beyond. Your community foundation has the resources and experience to help match you to causes and organizations that align with your passions. By staying informed, you can better understand how you can contribute to creating positive change, making your philanthropy even more impactful. 
  4. Donate. Whether from your checkbook or your donor advised fund, a financial contribution is a great way to show your appreciation for the dedicated work of your favorite causes and organizations.  Don‚Äôt have a donor advised fund? Cole Eason (mailto:eason@thcf.org), Vice-President of Advancement, would be happy to show you how to get started.

So, let's gear up to spread some love and kindness this National Philanthropy Day. Together, we can make our suburban Eastern Jackson County community a brighter and better place for everyone to live, work, and serve!
